title: Political Pins Were A Golden Globes Fashion Statement. Are They Enough?
text:
Political Pins Were A Golden Globes Fashion Statement. Are They Enough?

The 83rd annual Golden Globe Awards took place last night (January 11), and by all means, it was business as usual for the official kick-off to the 2026 awards season. Which, to be clear, isnâ€™t a good thing. As anyone whoâ€™s logging onto social media, turning on their TV, or doom scrolling on their TikTok FYP daily knows, the times are anything but normal â€” and we shouldnâ€™t be acting like they are.Â 

Kicking off the show, often touted as Hollywoodâ€™s biggest party, two-time host Nikki Glaser made a subtle allusion to the current political and social climate, welcoming celebs and viewers to the event that was â€œwithout a doubt the most important thing happening in the world right now.â€ And then, that was pretty much it.

To recap: the past year has seen a brutal decimation of human rights across the United States. Since the start of his second term in office, President Donald Trump and his administration have rolled back DEI initiatives across sectors, issued executive orders to end birthright citizenship and suspend the admission of refugees to the country, as well as targeted Transgender Americans by defining â€œsexâ€ as binary and proposing an immediate pause on gender-affirming care. In addition to this, his administration has increased funding to United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), deploying the National Guard into cities across the country and inciting violence. Earlier this month, a Minneapolis citizen, Renee Good, was shot and killed by an ICE agent. Oh, and the President of the United States is set to hold a UFC fight this July to celebrate his 80th birthday, held on the White Housesâ€™ South Lawn. (Which isnâ€™t a social injustice, but is tacky as hell).Â 

These are arguably the most unprecedented of unprecedented times; yet the Golden Globes felt like something straight out ofÂ  the 2016 feminism and activism handbook â€” ie: soap boxing with little to no substance. Talking around some of the most prevalent and dire issues of the moment without actually speaking to them in a way that would cause conversation or discomfort (which, to be clear, is needed).Â 

Presenting the award for Male Actor in a Limited Series, Anthology Series, Made for TV Movie, Kathryn Hahn and Melissa McCarthy took to the stage to sarcastically congratulate men on finally being recognized for their acting chops, as well as their abilities to show their range playing so many roles, as McCarthy put it â€œHusband! Ex-husband! Secretary! And everybodyâ€™s favorite: nosy neighbor.â€ It was a moment of comedy meant to be a tongue-in-cheek jab at ongoing conversations around menâ€™s dominance in the profession that failed to be either funny or actually impactful. The feeling was similar to actress Natalie Portmanâ€™s now-infamous statement at the 2018 Golden Globes while presenting the award for Best Director, where she pointedly called out the categoriesâ€™ list of all-male nominees. It was a strong statement, until you consider the fact that â€” between 2018 and this year â€” Portman has herself worked with no female directors. (In the words of queen Kirsten Dunst: â€œItâ€™s very simpleâ€ to work with female directors).Â 

Later in the show, Noah Wyle, the hunky lead of hit HBO series The PittÂ  â€“ which unflinching depicts the reality of being a healthcare worker in America â€” picked up two Golden Globe Awards, during which he broadly thanked healthcare workers, without speaking to any of the current ways in which the health care system is inaccessible to the majority of Americans. And Nikki Glaser ribbed Leonardo DiCaprio for continuing to date women under 30 instead of questioning why someone who claims to be a climate activist would attend Jeff Bezosâ€™ wedding.Â And even though One Battle After Another is a satire about revolution, critiquing anti-immigration and extremist white nationalist groups, those issues werenâ€™t directly addressed in the speeches when the film won.

It wasâ€¦dissapointing to say the least.Â 

Maybe this characterization is unfair. And some celebrities did subtly use their platforms for good last night. But the idea of asking and expecting celebrities to speak truth to power is nothing new. In fact, fans have been demanding it for years. Largely, these calls to action have been met with a divisive response from people both in and outside of the industry. In 2020, then- Golden Globes host Ricky Gervais directly warned celebrities not to talk about politics in their acceptance speeches, saying:Â  â€œYouâ€™re in no position to lecture the public about anything. You know nothing about the real world. Most of you spent less time in school than Greta Thunberg. If you win, come up, accept your little award, thank your agent and your god, and fuck off.â€Â 

In 2021, reflecting on that comment after yet another apolitical Golden Globe awards ceremony, Refinery29â€™s Senior Content Director, Entertainment Kathleen Newman-Bremang wrote about understanding the inclination to want to tell stars to essentially â€œshut up and look pretty.â€ Itâ€™s one that many stars we look to seem to hold, or at least cower behind, themselves.

In a November 2025 interview, Die My Love actress Jennifer Lawrence spoke about her decision to not speak openly about her politics, specifically the actions of President Donald Trump. In an interview with The New York Timesâ€™ The Interview podcast, Lawrence said that, after spending the Presidentâ€™s first term â€œrunning around like a chicken with [her] head cut off,â€ she felt speaking out wouldnâ€™t have an impact. â€œWeâ€™ve learned election after election, celebrities do not make a difference whatsoever on who people vote for,â€ Lawrence said. â€œSo then what am I doing? Iâ€™m just sharing my opinion on something thatâ€™s going to add fuel to a fire thatâ€™s ripping the country apart. We are so divided.â€

Lawrence went on to say that she wouldnâ€™t want her personal politics to deter people from coming to see her films, media that, in her words, could â€œchange consciousness or change the world.â€ While we admire the ambition and trust in her craft (and yes, it is true that art can literally change lives) â€” please, give us a break. Just say you donâ€™t want to alienate people that will contribute to your bottom line.Â 

But the fact remains that, despite what any comedians or Jennifer Lawrence may think, these celebrities and their platforms do have influence and can elicit change, especially when it comes to political leaders. When Taylor Swift publicly supported Kamala Harris ahead of the November 2024 Presidential election, sharing her intent to vote for the candidate on Instagram, she drove over 400,000 people to the vote.gov site over the next 24 hours. Bridgerton actress Nicola Coughlan, who has continued to post frequently to Palestinian aid organizations, has helped raise over $2 million USD to date.Â 

To be fair, thatâ€™s not to say that celebrities have completely eschewed speaking up and out about whatâ€™s currently happening in the country. Walking the red carpet ahead of the 83rd annual Golden Globes show, a handful of stars did speak out about the need for celebrities and lay people alike to be vocal about the current climate in the United States. Speaking to Refinery29, Poker Face actress Natasha Lyon, who donned a pin declaring ICE OUT, said: â€œI just think itâ€™s important that we donâ€™t normalize whatâ€™s going on in this country right now. I love America, I love us, I love our communities,Â  free speech, I love the Trevor Project and all that. I think itâ€™s important. Renee Good, say her name.â€ Lyon was one of several actors, including Tessa Thompson, Wanda Sykes, and Mark Ruffalo, who wore pins that said â€œBe Good,â€ speaking out against the actions of ICE and in support of Good and Keith Porter Jr., who was also killed by Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents. The Be Good campaign was launched by advocacy groups in response to ICEâ€™s $1000 million â€œwartime recruitment campaignâ€ aimed at expanding enforcement officers. Hacks star Hannah Einbinder also walked the carpet donning an Artists4Ceasefire pin â€” a red carpet fashion staple for her.

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Refinery29 (@refinery29)

Later on the same carpet, actress Yvette Nicole Brown was even more explicit with her distaste for the current administration, telling Refinery29â€™s Unbothered the thing thatâ€™s bothering her deeply is, simply: â€œOur government. That orange ghoul that is terrorizing us everyday,â€ before warning viewers that â€œitâ€™s about to be really real, get ready.â€

And while accepting her third Golden Globe for Actress in a Musical or Comedy Series, Hacks star Jean Smart also took her moment on-stage to encourage viewers to take action, saying: â€œThereâ€™s just a lot that could be said tonight; I said my rant on the red carpet, so I wonâ€™t do it hereâ€¦.But letâ€™s all do the right thing. I think everybody in their hearts knows what the right thing is to do. So letâ€™s do the right thing.â€ Smart was referring to earlier comments she made on the carpet, telling reporters that filming of the upcoming season of the show was overshadowed by the current goings on in the country, stating: â€œI feel like weâ€™re kind of at a turning point in this country, and I hope people can keep their heads because thatâ€™s actually, really, the hardest thing, I think, is to keep our heads. Itâ€™s going to take a lot of courage and concerns, but I think thatâ€™s important.â€

While fashion has long been political, and these small moments of resistance can be important,Â  itâ€™s hard to feel like a handful of celebs donning obscured, teeny-tiny pins or making veiled comments about triumphing over fear is enough, or anywhere near enough â€” because itâ€™s really not.

We need celebrities, with platforms and the ability to reach to and speak to people on every side of these issues, by virtue of their influence, to be vocal about the reality of whatâ€™s happening and what the impact is for everyone. We need these big names with big money and big studios attached to them to take action â€” whether thatâ€™s boycotting award shows or refusing to speak to anything other than these issues at this moment in time.Â 

It feels like the bare minimum, and actress Jameela Jamil agrees. Speaking to Refinery29 at the Spotify x The Hollywood Reporter Golden Globes Nominees Night, the British actress â€” who is a vocal activist â€” spoke to the inability of many of her colleagues to speak out against injustices, pondering, â€œAm I brave or are they cowards?â€

â€œI think theyâ€™re being greedy and weird and disappointing,â€ Jamil continued. â€œLook at the billions of eyeballs on all of us collectively, there should be no outliers of the industry who are the outspoken onesâ€¦out there on their own with this amount of privilege.â€ Jamil pointed to actors like Mark Ruffalo, who has often and vocally spoken out against injustices, noting that, when we look at people like him, we weaponize the word â€œbraveâ€ as a way to separate ourselves, removing ourselves from the expectation that we can and will do the same. â€œSo we rely on individuals to do what would be so much easier to achieve as a collective.â€Â 

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Refinery29 (@refinery29)

And if the Golden Globes are any indicator of what this upcoming awards season will hold when it comes to celebs speaking out, it feels like â€” once again â€” Ruffalo will be an outlier.Â 

But as disappointing as the apoliticalness of this awards show was, maybe the bigger disappointment is the fact that we continue to hope and ask for anything different from those we look up to onscreen, and continue to be disappointed when they donâ€™t follow through. Because truly, what can we really expect? At the end of the day, this industry is all about the bottom line. And our faves, who we idolize, meme, emulate and form a parasocial bond with, are largely going to stay on the side of the line that makes sure they get their bag â€“ as long as these injustices donâ€™t impact or affect them directly.Â 

So, for the next few months, award show contenders, winners, and Hollywood ingenues will have the spotlight on them. As they have every other awardsâ€™ season, theyâ€™ll thank their families and agents; tearfully, theyâ€™ll talk about hardship and determination, picking themselves up and trying again. And maybe itâ€™s time we stop hoping for more.Â

title: Donâ€™t Let January Fool You â€” I Think Sobriety Is Genuinely Fun
text:
Donâ€™t Let January Fool You â€” I Think Sobriety Is Genuinely Fun

Itâ€™s 8 p.m. on a Saturday in 2023 on my 30th birthday and I am standing on my own, stone-cold sober, wailing my way through Robbie Williamsâ€™ â€œAngelsâ€ at a crowded Italian restaurant in London. Up until this moment, karaoke had always been something I would have never done without drinking, in part because of my fear that people would judge me or find me embarrassing. But here I was, a year into sobriety, savoring the mad and euphoric feeling of being fully aware of my actions, surrounded by both loved ones and strangers, and not feeling a shred of social anxiety.

The biggest and most mortifying surprise of my life was just how much fun I could have without drinking. While I wouldnâ€™t say I was addicted to alcohol, I was definitely dependent on it throughout my twenties â€” it was my social lubricant and tool for emotional regulation in unfamiliar settings. Itâ€™s how I celebrated, commiserated, and ended an otherwise banal work day. Iâ€™d come to expect drinking to always equal fun and therefore fun to always equal drinking.

There were of course plenty of times when this wasnâ€™t true and the hangover, anxiety, and impact on my debit card showed it was far from worth it. But there was always the hope that this next dinner or night out or post-work drinks would be as glittering as some past one I remembered. Even when Iâ€™d tried reducing or stopping my drinking before â€”Â especially when I found it was triggering my debilitating obsessive compulsive disorder â€” I subconsciously held firm onto this idea that any fun I had sober would be even more fun when drinking.

It was only when I started a new medication for my OCD [Obsessive Compulsive Disorder] at the beginning of 2022 that I truly began to confront this idea. I stopped drinking and life went on. After a few pub evenings and birthday parties where I felt awkward and withdrawn, I began to embrace acting like a fool and being fully cognizant of it.

Celebrations became riotously fun as I had as much, if not more, fun as I ever did drinking. Two full years on, I maintain that stopping drinking is one of the best decisions Iâ€™ve made in my adult life. And more importantly, Iâ€™ve experienced all the fun and giddy glee sober that I was inadvertently chasing in a bottle.

This is why I am a firm believer that everyone who drinks should try life without alcohol in some capacity and that if you are considering quitting entirely, thereâ€™s no time like the present. But, now, as we roll into another unavoidably grey and miserly January, it is also why I think that for some, Dry January (spending the whole month sober as a mental and physical reset) might not be the way you begin to experience the joy of a reduced or even alcohol-free life.

I want to be very clear that Iâ€™m not criticizing Dry January. Itâ€™s a really important initiative led by the brilliant charity Alcohol Change UK, who do important work reducing alcohol harm. It also gives people a â€œsocially acceptableâ€ reason to stop drinking if they struggle with peer pressure. Moreover, peopleâ€™s relationship with alcohol varies greatly â€” the more dependent or addicted you are, the more you need to consult a professional, like your doctor, before making any big changes, and so the framing that works for me or someone else could be irrelevant for you.

There is no one-size-fits-all approach to reworking your relationship with alcohol, and for some people it may mean complete abstinence. Tara Swart Bieber, MD, tells us: â€œIf someone is misusing or abusing alcohol then medical supervision would be necessary if they wanted to stop. If someone stops and gets symptoms of withdrawal then they should contact their [doctor]. If they are drinking socially and not more than the recommended limits, then they can stop without medical guidance.â€

My point though is that taking a month off, especially in Januaryâ€™s grim weather and post-holiday-decadence haze, can just reaffirm the idea that sobriety is boring. As Annabelle Bonus, director of research, policy and strategy at Drinkaware UK, tells Refinery29: â€œInitiatives like Dry January can give people a really clear target if they want to cut down or try to stop drinking completely. While they work really well for some people, other people can find them hard to stick to and thatâ€™s completely normal.â€

Millie Gooch, founder of Sober Girl Society, a community safe space for sober women changing their relationship with alcohol, agrees. As an advocate for Dry January, she underlines why she supports the initiative. â€œWhere people might have overdone it over the holiday season, Dry January can provide a much-needed break for your body and mind,â€ she says. â€œOn the flip side, not much socializing happens in January and although this can make not drinking easier, it doesnâ€™t give you as much of a chance to flex your sober socializing muscles.â€ This can mean the idea of a dinner/night out/festival sober maintains a veneer of intimidation.

The way Iâ€™ve combatted this is to focus on getting in at least one social activity where you would in the past have been drinking and experiencing it sober. This can be intimidating at first, especially if you experience social anxiety in social situations. But one big secret I only realized when I stopped drinking is that pretty much everyone feels that way in new social situations. Iâ€™ve learned that it will dissipate after an hour or so as people relax â€” whether theyâ€™re drinking or not. And riding that anxiety out becomes far less challenging as you keep trying.

â€œThis [technique of riding out the anxiety] is one of the central tenets of exposure therapy,â€ explains Sheri Jacobson, PhD, a retired psychotherapist and founder of psychotherapy clinic Harley Therapy. â€œYou can track your anxiety on a self-reported scale one to 10, and you will notice the anxiety comes down at each 10-minute interval that passes. Most things will dissipate over time.â€

Dr. Jacobson emphasizes that itâ€™s psychologically important to make positive associations around not drinking, whether thatâ€™s just for one evening or for the foreseeable future.Â 

â€œWhat happens in drinking is that thereâ€™s a general lowering of inhibitions, which may allow us to speak more freely and be less anxious,â€ she explains. â€œThe short-term motivation is that we gain these benefits of maybe being more sociable than we would be and a greater sense of freedom. In order to stop drinking, we have to look at the things that are negative for us, and then switch those into something more positive.â€

The positives of not drinking are very clear to me. In my experience, it is not just those to your physical and mental health (though those are significant) but learning to overcome social anxiety in awkward situations, feeling at ease in yourself, having better ability to listen to your body when it says it needs food or rest, and then actively choosing to go home (or stay out). You can feel the crispness of euphoria in high definition without it being clouded by booze, you can dip out of repetitive, drunk conversations without anyone being offended (because theyâ€™re drunk), and save money. Whatâ€™s even more fun is that you channel it into something else, be it something youâ€™ve always wanted to try (pottery!) or silly little treats (chocolates!).

Drinking is fun and for many can be the spark that lights the best night of your life. But it doesnâ€™t have to be. Whether youâ€™re attempting Dry January or not, itâ€™s truly worth trying to have a good night without it â€”Â one thatâ€™s not just calm and clarified but raucous and silly, if thatâ€™s what you need.Â 

That wonâ€™t be guaranteed the first time you order a lime and soda at your local. As Bonus puts it: â€œWith any sort of behavior change, like cutting down drinking, it should be thought of as a journey rather than something thatâ€™s going to change overnight.â€ But if you find a whole month a prescriptive suggestion or youâ€™re worried that losing drinking will hamper your joy, I am proof that it wonâ€™t. And donâ€™t let the grim weather trick you into believing otherwise.

So yes, the People We Meet On Vacation movie is different from Emily Henryâ€™s novel â€” in a satisfying way.

And I think early on in my career, I was very fixated on trying to keep things as close to the book as possible,â€ Kuang tells Refinery29. â€œBut the reality that Iâ€™ve kind of learned over the period of time is that you canâ€™t actually just film a novel. Theyâ€™re very different things. Theyâ€™re very different mediums. And so to me, the task of the adaptation is not to be 100% faithful to the book.â€

This means die-hard book fans wonâ€™t see every single scene from the Emily Henry novel play out on screen, but while some have been removed, fresh new scenes have been introduced. Kuang says there are book scenes she would have loved to include, but itâ€™s impossible to fit everything into the script. And even if she writes the scenes, they donâ€™t always make it through the final edit. â€œThey end up on the cutting room floor for whatever reason, and each one of those is a small tragedy for the book purist who resides deep within my heart,â€ she jokes. â€œBut I think we also brought in a lot of things that I hope people will love too.â€

Thereâ€™s one particular scene near the start of the film which book fans wonâ€™t recognize, and it came about after the writers received feedback from Netflix. â€œI was really excited about that [new scene], because it felt like getting to construct Poppy (Emily Bader) and Alex (Tom Blyth) fanfic,â€ she says. â€œThereâ€™s definitely stuff that [book purists will] miss, because I miss it, but thereâ€™s also stuff that I hope will bring joy and delight as well.â€

Kuang is one of Henryâ€™s close collaborators, and while she canâ€™t tease too much about the upcoming Beach Read movie (theyâ€™re currently casting, and she just had a VFX meeting), she says their working relationship was â€œa dreamâ€ from the start. Henry has been generous with her energy, time and thoughts, allowing Kuang to connect with the source material on a deep level. â€œ[She would] provide me with these character maps of the characters that were always very helpful about, whatâ€™s driving them? Whatâ€™s the fear?â€ she says. â€œShe was so trusting, which I think, looking back now, that was such a gift.â€

Kuang is reluctant to confirm whether book purists will embrace People We Meet On Vacation, and quickly knocks on wood. â€œI hope they do, but you can never be too prescriptive,â€ she says. â€œI can say this. This film by everybody, by Emily, by Brett Haley, our director, by me and the other writers, Amos and Nunzio, it was all done with so much love and care and respect for this source materialâ€¦ it has to stand as a work on its own that hopefully feels like a love letter to the book.â€
